column3:
SEASONS When the silver wattle blooms, it signals that wallabies are in their birthing season. Consequently, we need to exercise greater caution when hunting wallaby during this period. Nature’s cues guide us, even in the hunt. After flowering, seeds can be gathered by laying a blanket down and brushing the branches to collect them.
FOOD The sap, when chewed or infused for a beverage, has a taste similar to flavourless chewing gum. As for the seeds, they are harvested either in their green state and subsequently dried, or directly when already dried out. These seeds can be consumed as-is or ground into flour for culinary purposes. 
MEDICINE 
Pollen for sleep enhancement While scientific evidence remains limited, traditional knowledge suggests that incorporating pollen from Acacia flowers into the diet may contribute to improved sleep quality.
Seeds as a hayfever preventive measure Consuming small quantities of seeds – particularly when they are still green – has been associated with mitigating hayfever symptoms and may reduce sensitivity to allergens and alleviate other allergic reactions.
Ash and sap for healing wounds Both ash and sap play essential roles in traditional wound care. When applied topically, ash can act as a natural antiseptic, aiding in wound sterilisation and promoting healing. Similarly, sap possesses soothing properties that facilitate tissue repair and alleviate discomfort caused by burns and sores.
Sap as a remedy for diarrhoea The potential of consuming sap to alleviate gastrointestinal distress is attributed to its mild astringent properties, which may help regulate bowel function.
TOOLS The ash and sap from the silver wattles are heated on the fire, usually in an abalone shell, then combined to make a strong glue.
column7: No information

column3:
FOOD The seeds, once dried then ground and cooked, serve as a viable food source. The sap extracted from the varnish wattle is also edible.
MEDICINE The sap possesses wound healing properties and can be applied as a dressing. For hayfever relief, consuming both the flowers and the seeds will alleviate symptoms.
TOOLS The leaves can be effectively employed as a fish poison.
column7:
FOOD Flowers are eaten fresh or mixed with flour to make damper.
MEDICINE The leaf is used for mild skin injuries such as cuts, stings and scratches. It is also made into a decoction to bathe sores and boils.

column3:
FOOD The sap is water soluble and is made into drinks.
MEDICINE Flowers can help to reduce hayfever symptoms (but also cause hayfever in some people), while the gum can be dissolved in water and drunk to prevent diarrhoea and to alleviate indigestion. Bark-infused water can be used as a cough MEDICINE and lotion for skin irritations such as eczema.
TOOLS The sap is mixed with wood ashes in hot water to make a water-tight cement. The inner bark is used for string and the outer bark is good for wooden implements bowls and coolamons, as well as tanning for wallaby, possum and kangaroo skins.
column7: No information

column3:
FOOD The black seeds can be eaten when roasted, dried or ground and mixed with water or animal fats to make damper. This is the 'the seed of the lightwood' Robinson mentioned in his diary on 30 January 1834. (See also Acacia leprosa var. graveolens.)
MEDICINE The bark is heated and rubbed/wrapped on sore rheumatic joints. It can also help headaches, colds and fever.
TOOLS The inner bark fibres are used for fishing line, and the wood for clubs, clap sticks and throwing sticks. The bark may be used as a container/coolamon. The bark is an effective fish poison. The white ash can be used for paint.

There are also three subspecies in Lutruwita.
FOOD The sap is eaten straight from the tree. The dried seeds are also edible but difficult to harvest due to the spiky leaves.
MEDICINE The sap is applied to wounds to aid healing and keep out infection.
TOOLS The bark is used for string and fishing line.
SEASONS, When the flowers are out, this is a visual reminder that the echidnas are breeding and laying eggs, so we must be more careful when hunting.niyakara  
One day, three hunters went out to catch rraykana/emu for dinner. The cheeky spirit decided he would run between the hunters and the rraykana, so the rraykana could get away. The hunters had to stop trying to catch their dinner and chased after the spirit, but they were too quick. The spirit ran into a big thick bush of raprina, so when the hunters tried to go after the spirit, they got covered in all the prickles. The hunters had to sit down and make a fire to keep warm while they pulled out all the prickles and made a new plan. Before long, the cheeky one came back, running around the fire kicking the hot coals and ashes at the hunters. The youngest hunter had an idea. He decided he would throw the prickles at the spirit, and when the other hunters joined in, before too long the spirit was completely covered in prickles and slowed right down, then changed into trimanya, the echidna. To honour the persistence and courage of trimanya, when raprina is in flower, we do not hunt female trimanya.

column3:
FOOD The root tubers can be eaten, fresh or dried, and ground up for flour.
CAUTION Take utmost care when harvesting to make sure replanting is successful. Early recorded sightings of the orchids listed in this book indicate that white people may not have heeded this caution. The French naturalist, Ferdinand Péron, who visited Tasmania on the Baudin expedition (1800–1803), noted taking ‘orchid bulbs in bag’ (A voyage of discovery to the southern hemisphere, 1809, vol. 1, p. 193). And the English botanist and missionary James Backhouse recorded ‘a number of Orchids eaten’ (Narrative of a visit to the Australian colonies, 1843, appendix d., p. xxxvii).

FOOD The sap is chewed and can be soaked in hot water to make jelly. The seeds can be harvested to make flour from the tree’s capsules, but this is more laborious than taking seed from the drooping sheoak (see Allocasuarina verticillata).
TOOLS The wood is excellent for digging sticks and throwing sticks. 
OTHER patrula/FIRE Dry cracked logs are used as a base for fire making, the cracks being filled with fine wood shavings and the drill rubbed up and down in the crack, using the fire-plow method where the rubbing produces friction, heat and then embers.

FOOD When ripe, the blueish purple fruits may be eaten fresh or roasted in the coals. Fruits can also be dried to preserve them. I prefer to remove the small seeds prior to eating, although this isn’t necessary.

TOOLS The vines are made into string, which is also used for baskets, and the berries used for dye.
CAUTION Be incredibly careful not to confuse with other blue berries, some of which are poisonous and can be fatal.

FOOD The single-stoned mucilaginous fruit can be eaten straight from the vine. It has a pine flavour. 
On 10 February 1830 Robinson records: ‘in the course of the day my Aboriginal guide gave me a wild fruit resembling a greengage’ (p. 148).
MEDICINE The stem is soaked in water and drunk to bring a fever down, and helps relieve head and body aches. The unripe fruit can be eaten for stomach pains and crushed and applied to sores, cuts, wounds and lesions to stop bleeding.
TOOLS The whole vine is used for a quick fishing net, thrown and anchored across creeks to catch fish and eels.

MEDICINE The berries can be used for medicinal purposes to help treat stomach pains. They are mashed and applied externally or eaten in very small quantities.
CAUTION Generally NOT edible

These ferns grow at a very slow rate. Carbon dating indicates some may be as old as 2,000 years.
FOOD Inside the top of the trunk is a white pithy substance, which can be eaten when cooked, although this does kill the plant. While still curled, the new fronds (croziers) may be cooked in very hot coals and eaten.
These ferns caught the attention of early naturalists. Robinson, Backhouse and Maiden noted their bitter, astringent taste when raw, saying Cyathea was preferred. And Backhouse observed the ‘pith from about 18 inches of the top of the trunk was removed, roasted in ashes’, while Robinson noted that they were ‘eaten with kangaroo. Wedges of charred wood used to split stem; roasting destroys bitterness’ (Plomley, 1991).
CAUTION This plant contains shikimic acid, which is a known carcinogenic. Edible parts of this plant must be cooked at high temperatures to remove traces of the acid. The wood from silver wattle (Acacia dealbata) burns extremely hot and is the preferred fire to cook these ferns.
MEDICINE The young raw fronds of this plant are crushed and used as MEDICINE for scratches and stings. The root sap makes a strong ointment for burns and blisters. 
TOOLS The fronds may also be used for shelter and the dry fluff from the trunk for fire lighting.

SEASONS When the grass flowers, it is a seasonal indicator for snakes becoming livelier.
FOOD The white flesh at the base of the leaf has a similar taste to celery and can be eaten but it is not as good as Lomandra longifolia.
TOOLS The leaves are also used to make string and weave baskets. They are drawn through the flames of the fire, which makes them soft and limp, and then twined together.

There are 29 species of Epacris in Tasmania, 23 are endemic. All Epacris flowers are edible.
FOOD Flowers may be added to flour to sweeten breads.

MEDICINE helpful in treating wounds, burns, and skin irritations. The plant is also used to make a tea that is used to treat diarrhea and dysentery. High in antioxidants also edible young shoots and leaves

MEDICINE helpful in treating wounds, burns, and skin irritations. The plant is also used to make a tea that is used to treat diarrhea and dysentery. High in antioxidants also edible young shoots and leaves, also used to treat urinary tract problems
FOOD The root/tubers can be eaten.

MEDICINE The leaves are crushed and the scent inhaled to relieve blocked noses. The smoke from the green leaves is antibacterial and antifungal, great for breathing difficulties and lung conditions like asthma.
TOOLS The young root balls of the trees make great waddies; the smaller branches are used to make clap sticks, throwing sticks and digging sticks.

FOOD The sap has a high sugar content and is collected and drunk fresh or fermented. On 16 December 1831, Robinson wrote (Friendly Mission, p.589): ‘The melliferous cider tree was growing most luxuriantly, some of them twelve feet in circumference, and the liquid was oozing out in tolerable quantities. Holes at the bottom of those trees had been made to receive the juice and which answered the purpose of the tank. Some of the liquor had dried and was white and resembled in appearance and taste a bruised apple; some was brown. It was amusing to see the natives run from tree to tree to suck this juice, of which they are very fond. The birds may be seen attacking this tree for the luscious juice; the animals also resort to these trees for the same purpose, i.e. the opossum.’ 
OTHER CULTURAL The fermented sap is used for ceremonial purposes and in other cultural practices.

TOOLS The inner bark fibres can be made into string for bags, nets and strong rope, while the outer bark is a useful source for tinder for making fire and firesticks (to carry fire). The outer bark can also be used to build shelters, make canoes and for decoration. The sap is effective as a stain or dye. The young trees make great waddies.
When harvesting the bark, we never take more than one third of the circumference so that we do not ringbark the tree. We also cover the area that has been stripped of bark with mud to stop insects and to help the tree heal.
All Eucalypts have cultural significance

TOOLS The wood may be used to make implements such as flat shields and containers. The young saplings are used for waddies.
MEDICINE to treat and prevent migrains and headaches,
MEDICINE The gum that forms on the leaf tips may be applied to cuts and grazes as an antiseptic and can also help stop bleeding.

Lutruwita has five native species of Exocarpus, a member of the sandalwood family. ‘Exo’ means outer, and ‘carpos’ fruit: the seeds are on the outside of the fruit, like cashews and strawberries. These are exceptional trees for several reasons. They are hemi-parasitic, meaning they use the roots of other trees for a water source. This makes them extremely hard to propagate. 
Always look after the trees around the native cherry trees, as they are important for their survival. 
FOOD The red fruits are high in vitamin C; they are delicious. To eat, hold the in-built handle, the outer seed, and bite off the fruit. The brighter, darker red fruits are the sweetest.
MEDICINE The young leaf tips and sap have coagulant properties. They are crushed into a pulp and applied to wounds that are bleeding. The young leaf tips are part of traditional snakebite remedies. 
TOOLS The wood can be used for clapsticks and digging sticks. The leaves and wood make a lovely green or red dye.
OTHER CEREMONY Leaves are used for smoking ceremonies.

FOOD The fruit may be eaten raw or cooked. 
MEDICINE The half-ripe fruits can be prepared as a medicinal drink for stomach complaints.

FOOD The seeds can be gathered, ground to make flour and mixed with water or animal fat to make a damper-like substance, which is then baked in the coals. The seeds are extremely hard.
TOOLS The leaf is extraordinarily strong and can be used to make rope strong enough for tree climbing.
CAUTION The edges of the leaves are extremely sharp and can even cut through bone.
used to treat skin ailments, wounds and digestive issues. Diuretic and lymphatic drainage. Also edible leaves and stems in soups and stews

FOOD The root tubers are dug up and eaten raw or baked in coals, with at least one-third of the yield replanted for next season. Prior to colonisation, lanapana was a staple food for our ancestors.
Robinson recorded on 9 December 1831: ‘It was during our walk this morning that I observed the native women of the Big River tribe dig out of the ground the native potato’ (Friendly Mission, p. 579).
FOOD The small white fruit is edible and sweet. It should be eaten when picked as the fruits do not store well and turn brown easily and quickly.

FOOD The thickened taproot is branched or radish-like. Sometimes the reddish root is cooked before being eaten. The flower may be eaten raw or mixed with other plants and cooked. 
MEDICINE The leaves can be crushed and applied to burns and blisters.

patrula/FIRE Plains of ti   puna plains are found all over Lutruwita, from the coastal areas in the southwest and on the Freycinet Peninsula all the way up to the Central Highlands. Palawa people have a profound connection with tipuna: the areas we see today are a poignant visual reminder of just how long our ancestors have lived here for. More than 2,000 generations of people have cared for this beautiful Country and these areas are evidence of the oldest known farming technique in the world, now known as firestick farming. tipuna relies on regular burning. At the right time, in the right conditions this helps the grass to thrive and promotes seeds and flowering, which lots of animals depend on for food.

There are 10 species of hakea in Lutruwita. 
TOOLS The sap from all species can be used as an adhesive.

There are 25 native species of Juncus, three of which are endemic to Lutruwita and 13 introduced species.  All the larger species are used to build our canoes. Juncus pallidus and Juncus kraussii grow the largest of the species, which is why I have chosen these ones to describe here.
FOOD The seeds can be ground and cooked or eaten raw. They have a very grassy flavour.
MEDICINE The central pith is used as an anti-inflammatory, diuretic and for fever reduction and urinary problems.
TOOLS The leaf is used for string and baskets. The leaves are scraped with a mussel shell, dried, then soaked for use or, when green, run through the flames then scraped and used for fishing line, bags and nets. The reed resists rotting. It makes great flooring and bedding. 
The whole stem of the larger species (Juncus pallidus and Juncus krausii) are used in the construction of canoes: this reed is what helps the canoe to float.
Labillardière records baskets made from Juncus, ‘J. acutus’, (probably J. kraussii)), (Voyage in search of La Pérouse, 1880, p. 121).

There are 25 native species of Juncus, three of which are endemic to Lutruwita and 13 introduced species.  All the larger species are used to build our canoes. Juncus pallidus and Juncus kraussii grow the largest of the species, which is why I have chosen these ones to describe here.
FOOD The seeds can be ground and cooked or eaten raw. They have a very grassy flavour.
MEDICINE The central pith is used as an anti-inflammatory, diuretic and for fever reduction and urinary problems.
TOOLS The leaf is used for string and baskets. The leaves are scraped with a mussel shell, dried, then soaked for use or, when green, run through the flames then scraped and used for fishing line, bags and nets. The reed resists rotting. It makes great flooring and bedding. 
The whole stem of the larger species (Juncus pallidus and Juncus krausii) are used in the construction of canoes: this reed is what helps the canoe to float.
Labillardière records baskets made from Juncus, ‘J. acutus’, (probably J. kraussii)), (Voyage in search of La Pérouse, 1880, p. 121).

tools, weaving

TOOLS The leaf is used as the red contrast in baskets made from Lomandra longifolia: the leaves are dried, soaked, cut to separate the upper and lower epidermis. Then the inside tissue is scraped out.
TOOLS The leaf base is red and is used as a contrast colour in baskets. It requires preparation to remove the cutting edges before use.

FOOD The seeds are edible.
TOOLS The long flat leaves are used for weaving baskets and string. Lay the leaves over the fire, then split them longways, twist them to make string.

FOOD The small white-centred, berries of all these species are edible. The red or pink drupes are edible. The fruit can be eaten raw or cooked. 
CAUTION Eating these fruits will not alleviate dehydration as they cause dryness in the mouth.

FOOD The abundant nectar from the raw flowers and unripe fruit may be used as a drink. The ripe fruits are delicious and a little sour, similar to lemon.
MEDICINE A drink made from the crushed berries can be used to treat sore throats.

Of the eight species in Lutruwita, five are endemic. Many species produce a lot of nectar, which makes them a favourite of bees. The honey is often marketed as manuka honey. Teatree oil is used as an anti-inflammatory, antiseptic, antibacterial and antifungal ointment.

FOOD The flowers and leaves can be soaked in warm water for tea.
MEDICINE The half green leaves may be burned to function as a deterrent to biting insects around the campsite. An antiseptic is made from crushed fresh leaves.
TOOLS The bark is bundled and tied together with either Juncus or Typha. to form a canoe and the wood used to make a spear.

SEASONS For the Big River mob, the flower is an indicator of the seasonal arrival of seafoods, signalling it being time to move to the coast for gathering.
FOOD The nectar may be eaten or drunk with water.
MEDICINE The leaf and seed capsule may be crushed and used as a MEDICINE for the mouth and body. Antiseptic poultice can be made from leaves
TOOLS The wood is used for spears, throwing sticks and walking sticks, and whole branches for huts as well as pegs for tanning skins/hides.

The flowers and fruits of all eight Tasmanian species of Leucopogon are edible.
FOOD The fruit is a delicious berry that can be eaten fresh or dried then added to flour or stews. Robinson ‘[d]iscovered a variety of berries which the natives eat, among which were the native currant, of white colour and pleasant flavour’ (8 February 1830 in Port Davey, Friendly Mission, p. 147).
MEDICINE The raw unripe fruits can be eaten or crushed with water and drunk as a liver tonic.

The flowers and fruits of all eight Tasmanian species of Leucopogon are edible.
FOOD The fruit is a delicious berry that can be eaten fresh or dried then added to flour or stews. Robinson ‘[d]iscovered a variety of berries which the natives eat, among which were the native currant, of white colour and pleasant flavour’ (8 February 1830 in Port Davey, Friendly Mission, p. 147).
MEDICINE The raw unripe fruits can be eaten or crushed with water and drunk as a liver tonic.

FOOD The white part at the base of the leaf and the root has a delicious snow pea flavour and can be eaten directly from ground. It is best to get a bulb, which can range in size from a spring onion to leek. The leaf base can be enjoyed all year round. The seeds may be eaten when green, and either roasted or ground to make flour. The flowers are also edible and quite sweet. They can be eaten fresh or soaked in water for a sweet drink. 
TOOLS The leaves are used as string and to weave baskets. 
CAUTION The edges of leaves are sharp and can cause serious cuts. The seed heads are spiky so use care when harvesting.
FOOD The flower is edible.
FOOD The flower is edible.
used to induce vomitind, can have hypnotic/intoxicating effects if large dose taken

MEDICINE The nectar may be gathered and drunk as a remedy for a sore throat, while the leaf has antiseptic properties and is applied as a bandage to cuts and grazes. Crushed leaves can be used as an inhalant for chest complaints or as a mouth and body wash. 
TOOLS The bark is used to wrap babies and as clothing; to wrap food and to make shelter, rafts and canoes. The wood is good for making waddies, clapsticks, digging sticks and throwing sticks.

FOOD The nectar from the flower is mixed with water for a sweet drink.
MEDICINE The nectar can also aid sore throats. 
TOOLS The wood is used for tool making.

FOOD The flowers provide nectar for sweet drinks.
MEDICINE The crushed leaves are antiseptic and applied to insect bites. The leaves can also be boiled and the steam inhaled.

MEDICINE The nectar may be gathered and drunk as a remedy for a sore throat, while the leaf has antiseptic properties and is applied as a bandage to cuts and grazes. Crushed leaves can be used as an inhalant for chest complaints or as a mouth and body wash. 
TOOLS The bark is used to wrap babies and as clothing; to wrap food and to make shelter, rafts and canoes. The wood is good for making waddies, clapsticks, digging sticks and throwing sticks.

FOOD The flowers provide nectar for sweet drinks. The best way to gather the nectar is to dunk the flowers in a bowl of water, while they are still attached to the tree. This means that you can return the next day and gather more, and that the birds, insects and possums can still share in the bounty too.

FOOD The young leaves are tasty steamed or boiled. They are also great for wrapping foods like fish before cooking.
MEDICINE The leaves make good bandages.

FOOD The ripe fruit may be eaten raw.
MEDICINE Unripe fruit is made into a drink and used as a liver tonic.
FOOD The small blackish fruit may be eaten raw, and the seeds can be ground to make flour.
FOOD The small blackish fruit may be eaten raw, and the seeds can be ground to make flour.

TOOLS The wood is used for spears, throwing sticks and digging sticks.

FOOD The fruit is edible but very bitter. 
MEDICINE The fruits and leaves are used for tonics for internal discomfort such as an upset stomach.
FOOD The orange ball fungi (Cyttaria gunnii) is edible.
Food The seeds are edible and large amounts can be collected from a single bush. Dry and crush the seeds and add to bread dough, cakes or biscuits.

MEDICINE warm decoction of rhizome applied to boils, boiled leaves applied to wounds. Leaf juice ingested to stop heart spasms
Oreomyrrhis sessiliflora - FOOD The leaf and root may be eaten raw or cooked and used as a flavouring that smells like carrots.

FOOD The root may be cooked and eaten.

FOOD The hard fruit seed is slightly roasted then cracked and the nut inside eaten or mixed with other plant ingredients. The sweet flesh from around the seed can also be eaten.
MEDICINE The sticky juice and the fibrous material is scraped off the green, unripe fruit seed and applied to burns, scratches and rashes.

FOOD The hard fruit seed is slightly roasted then cracked and the nut inside eaten or mixed with other plant ingredients. The sweet flesh from around the seed can also be eaten.
MEDICINE The sticky juice and the fibrous material is scraped off the green, unripe fruit seed and applied to burns, scratches and rashes.

MEDICINE The leaves can be bound around the face and inhaled as MEDICINE. Sore joints can be bound with bark.
TOOLS The bark can be made into an extraordinarily strong and hardy string or rope for the construction of nets and canoes. It is toxic and must be prepared with caution by stripping the bark and weighting it down in running water for days until the non- fibrous parts rot. It can then be dried in the sun and beaten with sticks or flat rocks to make into the finest, yet strong, string. 
CAUTION THIS PLANT IS TOXIC. If the bark is not treated correctly while preparing the string, within two minutes of touching exposed fresh bark, a massive headache will follow.

TOOLS The wood is used for making waddies and throwing sticks. The throwing stick is pointed at both ends. It was about 70 to 75 cm long and 2.5 cm in diameter and is thrown for hunting but is also used for digging. 
In 1848, the chief clerk in the Governor of Tasmania’s office, Hugh Munro Hull, presented to the Royal Society of Tasmania ‘a sample of an exceptionally fine close-grained white timber...it is the young wood of Pittosporum bicolor, formerly in high estimation amongst the Aborigines of Tasmania, on account of its combined qualities of density, hardness, and tenacity, as the most suitable material of which to make their war-like implement, the waddie’ (Roth, p.70).

Of the 13 native species in Lutruwita, six are endemic and five are introduced.
FOOD The leaves and seeds are edible.
MEDICINE The leaves are good for skin conditions, including for healing wounds.

FOOD The seeds can be made into flour.
TOOLS The leaf is used for fine weaving and fine string making, while the dry leaf can be used to make fire and for hut thatching.

There are 10 species in Lutruwita.
TOOLS The wooden stems are sharpened and used as pegs for tanning skins. The straight tough stems are suitable for spears and are used for hut frames and clapsticks. 
The leaves make great toilet paper!

FOOD The leaves have a mint flavour for tea and are used as a seasoning.
MEDICINE The leaves may be crushed to aid in breastfeeding. Leaves are steamed and inhaled for blocked nose and headaches. A warm wash is used for body aches. Crushed leaves are rubbed on the chest for chest infections. Crushed leaves are also added to animal fats to make a cream/ointment to treat body aches and skins sores.
TOOLS The wood is used as a fire drill to make fire.

SEASONS The new curly fiddleheads indicate the jack-jumpers/bull-ants/inch-mans will become more active as the weather is warming up. These parts of the plant are, in turn, the best MEDICINE for these bites and stings.
FOOD The thin white strands of the inside of rhizomes (underground stem) may be eaten. They taste like celery and are a reliable source of fibre. The new brown shoots are best eaten cooked. The rhizome is roasted in ashes and the black skin peeled off. The curly new fiddlehead leaves are eaten fresh or roasted in hot ashes, beaten into a paste with a stone then eaten; they taste like walnuts.
MEDICINE This plant has high levels of shikimic acid, which has powerful anti-cancer, antiviral and antibacterial properties. It regenerates tissue and has anticoagulant and antithrombotic properties but see the caution below. It is the juice from rhizomes and squashed leaves that are applied to ant bites and stings. 
CAUTION In addition to shikimic acid, there are other chemicals in this plant, which can make it dangerous if consumed in large quantities.
TOOLS Dried old leaves are great fire starters.
FOOD The root may be eaten raw or cooked. Gentle harvesting with a digging stick promotes plentiful new growth.

FOOD The leaf and stem may be eaten raw. MEDICINE Eating the leaf and stem is good pain relief and promotes sleep. The stem milk is put on warts and sores. The plant is also used for traditional women’s business.

FOOD The moss can be used to filter and clean water so that it is safe to drink.
MEDICINE Dried moss is highly absorbent and has many applications such as babies’ nappies and wound dressings.
TOOLS Dried moss is a great fire starter.

There are five species in Lutruwita, three of which are listed as rare.
OTHER: A GAME When the flower is touched, the style snaps over suddenly.

There are five species in Lutruwita, three of which are listed as rare.
OTHER: A GAME When the flower is touched, the style snaps over suddenly.
FOOD The fruit may be eaten raw.

FOOD The leaves are much spicier than the berries and can be used for flavouring in cooking. The crushed fresh berries are a beautiful purple and look great in potato, pasta or chicken dishes. Leaves are good in pumpkin soup (chop them finely).
CAUTION Very spicy!
MEDICINE The black berry, leaves and bark are made into a tea with hot water and drunk as a pain killer. The unripe berries and leaves provide, when crushed, a good cream for infected sores and rashes. The leaves, stems, flowers and fruits all have anti-fungal, anti-microbial and anti-inflammatory properties. The leaves and fruits can be chewed for toothache: I figure once you are on fire from the spiciness, you forget about the pain!

FOOD The nectar from the flower can be mixed with water to make a sweet drink.
MEDICINE Nectar mixed with water is good for a sore throat.

FOOD The root tuber may be roasted and eaten. The leaves are also edible.
Plomley (Westlake Papers, 1991, pp. 23, 39, 66, 76) cites the following description, recorded about 1910 by Tasman Smith, ‘a very good witness’ and Tasmanian descendant: ‘grows about 18 inches, like a young oat with a thicker leaf, the large ones 3/4 inch wide but a grass not a vegetable. Has roots like potato, an inch long and half an inch thick; four or five. A blue flower like a potato. Roast it. Green leaves good to eat.’ While Smith mentions the Aboriginal word that would indicate he was referring to sun orchids, his reference to ‘four or five’ tubers would seem to indicate Caesia, rather than Thelymitra, which has paired tubers.

FOOD The root tuber may be roasted and eaten. The leaves are also edible.
Plomley (Westlake Papers, 1991, pp. 23, 39, 66, 76) cites the following description, recorded about 1910 by Tasman Smith, ‘a very good witness’ and Tasmanian descendant: ‘grows about 18 inches, like a young oat with a thicker leaf, the large ones 3/4 inch wide but a grass not a vegetable. Has roots like potato, an inch long and half an inch thick; four or five. A blue flower like a potato. Roast it. Green leaves good to eat.’ While Smith mentions the Aboriginal word that would indicate he was referring to sun orchids, his reference to ‘four or five’ tubers would seem to indicate Caesia, rather than Thelymitra, which has paired tubers.

FOOD The young stem and new curled leaf are roasted and eaten.
MEDICINE The raw fronds are crushed with sap from the centre of the root to make a medicinal poultice for infected sores and insect stings.

FOOD The root and stem may be eaten raw or cooked.
MEDICINE The raw juice from the stems and tuber is good MEDICINE for small rashes and blisters.
SENSITIVE Trachymene humilis subsp. breviscapa and Trachymene composita subsp. robertsonii are likely to qualify as threatened.

FOOD The purplish-blue berries are edible.
CAUTION Do not confuse with some other Tasmanian bluish berries, which are not edible and can be fatal.

In Lutruwita, there are two native species and one introduced (Typha latifolia).
FOOD The white leaf base and root tuber is eaten raw or cooked and has a taste like watermelon crossed with cucumber. 
MEDICINE The gel from the stem is like aloe vera and is good for burns and skin rashes. The seed heads are very absorbent and used as padding for babies’ nappies. The leaves are strappy and good for bandaging.
TOOLS The leaves can be bundled together and wrapped with paperbark or stringybark for a canoe, something Péron recorded when on Maria Island: ‘the stalks of [a new species of Typha, from] which the inhabitants make their canoes’ (Péron, 1809, p. 233). And Robinson recorded, while in northeast Tasmania, seeing five bundles of dry leaves lashed together for a catamaran. He said the rushes were quite dry (Typha is dry in winter) and 'is the same which they eat' (in Friendly Mission, p. 399).
The leaves are also dried then soaked and made into string for baskets.
The seed heads are soaked in oil/animal fat and used as a torch for nighttime.

FOOD The young tips of the leaves are edible. Cooking removes the sting of the plant. 
MEDICINE The leaves may be slapped repeatedly on areas of rheumatic pain to relieve discomfort. Boiled leaf is used for muscle strains and for boils.
CAUTION Like its close relative, the introduced Utrica urens or stinging nettle, this plant STINGS. Wear hand coverings when harvesting.
MEDICINE leaves for food and MEDICINE-anti inflammatory, respiratory, rubbed on itchy skin to ease itching WARNING can have interactions with western MEDICINEs
MEDICINE respiritory, gastrointestinal, urinary tract infections, and skin conditions and rheumatism

Lutruwita has nine native species, one of which is endemic.
FOOD The flowers can be eaten fresh and are a wonderful addition to salads.
SENSITIVE Some of these violets are rare or endangered.
FOOD The flowers of all eight species are edible.

FOOD The gum may be eaten, as can the crystallised honeydew produced by lerp insects.
MEDICINE The leaf can be crushed and inhaled to clear a blocked nose and used as a decoction to apply to sores. The green leaves are burned and used for smoking ceremonies, to smoke out a fever and to repel insects. 
TOOLS The wood may be used to make implements such as flat shields and containers. The young saplings are used for waddies.
MEDICINE eyes, respiratory and anti inflammatory

Depends on the species. i.e. Plantago lanceolata has uses for
FOOD The leaves and seeds are edible.
MEDICINE The leaves are good for skin conditions, including for healing wounds.

FOOD The seeds can be made into flour.
TOOLS The leaf is used for fine weaving and fine string making, while the dry leaf can be used to make fire and for hut thatching.
FOOD The root may be eaten raw or cooked. Gentle harvesting with a digging stick promotes plentiful new growth.
